Measurement_Method: 353 CpG sites via Illumina 450K/EPIC array; elastic net regression trained on 8000 samples across 51 cell types
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate (EAA +5yr ~ 15-20% increased mortality risk)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Moderate (responds to CR, TRIIM trial -2.5yr, lifestyle interventions -3.23yr, CaAKG)
Key_Publication: Horvath S. DNA methylation age of human tissues and cell types. Genome Biol. 2013;14(10):R115
Notes: Most widely cited epigenetic clock; multi-tissue applicability; MAE ~3.6 years; first-generation clock trained on chronological age

Measurement_Method: 71 CpG sites from whole blood via Illumina 450K/EPIC array; elastic net regression trained on 656 blood samples
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate (similar to Horvath; outperformed by GrimAge and PhenoAge)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Moderate (responds to some lifestyle and pharmacological interventions)
Key_Publication: Hannum G et al. Genome-wide methylation profiles reveal quantitative views of human aging rates. Mol Cell. 2013;49(2):359-367
Notes: Blood-specific; simpler model (71 CpGs); MAE ~4.9 years; does not work well on non-blood tissues

Developer: Morgan Levine (Yale/Altos Labs) and Steve Horvath (UCLA)
Measurement_Method: Two-step: phenotypic age from 9 clinical biomarkers + chronological age, then 513 CpG DNAm predictor via elastic net; blood-based Illumina 450K/EPIC
Correlation_With_Mortality: Strong (HR ~1.04-1.05 per year of acceleration; predicts CVD, cancer, multi-morbidity)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Moderate to High (responds to CR, weight loss, pharmacological agents; clinical biomarker basis increases metabolic responsiveness)
Key_Publication: Levine ME et al. An epigenetic biomarker of aging for lifespan and healthspan. Aging (Albany NY). 2018;10(4):573-591
Notes: Trained on mortality-relevant phenotypic data; phenotypic age component calculable from standard blood tests; affected by acute illness

Developer: Ake Lu and Steve Horvath / UCLA
Measurement_Method: 1030 CpG sites; DNAm surrogates for 7 plasma proteins (adrenomedullin, beta-2 microglobulin, cystatin C, GDF-15, leptin, PAI-1, TIMP-1) + smoking pack-years; blood via Illumina EPIC array
Correlation_With_Mortality: Very Strong (strongest epigenetic mortality predictor; HR ~1.07-1.10 per year of acceleration; predicts CHD, cancer, T2D, COPD)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: High (responds to CR via CALERIE trial, weight loss, exercise, smoking cessation; primary endpoint in PEARL rapamycin trial)
Key_Publication: Lu AT et al. DNA methylation GrimAge strongly predicts lifespan and healthspan. Aging (Albany NY). 2019;11(2):303-327
Notes: Best mortality predictor among epigenetic clocks (confirmed NIA 2025); captures smoking exposure; blood-based only; requires Illumina EPIC array

Developer: Ake Lu and Steve Horvath / UCLA
Measurement_Method: Updated version of GrimAge with improved accuracy; same Illumina EPIC array platform and methylation surrogate approach
Correlation_With_Mortality: Very Strong (improved over original GrimAge)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: High (same intervention sensitivity profile as GrimAge with improved precision)
Key_Publication: Lu AT et al. DNA methylation GrimAge version 2. Aging (Albany NY). 2022;14(23):9484-9549
Notes: Updated coefficients and improved accuracy over original GrimAge; recommended for new studies over original version

Developer: Daniel Belsky (Columbia), Avshalom Caspi and Terrie Moffitt (Duke)
Measurement_Method: 173 CpG sites via Illumina EPIC array from blood; trained on Dunedin Longitudinal Study (1037 individuals, 19 repeated measures over 20+ years); measures RATE of aging not biological age
Correlation_With_Mortality: Strong (each 0.1-unit increase ~ 10-15% increased mortality risk; predicts all-cause, CVD, and cancer mortality)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Excellent (most sensitive to interventions; CALERIE trial reduced pace ~2-3%; responds to lifestyle modifications; designed for intervention sensitivity)
Commercial_Availability: Yes (TruDiagnostic TruAge panel, exclusive commercial license)
Key_Publication: Belsky DW et al. DunedinPACE, a DNA methylation biomarker of the pace of aging. eLife. 2022;11:e73420
Notes: Measures rate of aging (value of 1.0 = normative); most clinically actionable; ideal for clinical trial endpoints; Dunedin cohort is predominantly European-ancestry

Measurement_Method: Integrates DNA methylation with metabolomic, proteomic, and clinical biomarker data for composite biological age estimate
Correlation_With_Mortality: Unknown (early validation reported)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Unknown (theoretical advantage from multi-omic integration)
Key_Publication: Not yet available as standalone peer-reviewed publication
Notes: Represents trend toward multi-omic integration; hypothesis is that combining molecular modalities captures more aging dimensions than single-omic clocks

Measurement_Method: Composite clock integrating multiple epigenetic and omic signals into a unified aging score
Correlation_With_Mortality: Unknown (under active validation)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Unknown (early-stage assessment)
Key_Publication: Not yet available as standalone peer-reviewed publication
Notes: Newer composite clock; included in TruDiagnostic reporting panels; less independent validation than established clocks

Measurement_Method: Cheek swab (buccal sample); custom DNA methylation panel; proprietary CheekAge clock algorithm
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate (CheekAge reported to predict mortality in validation cohorts)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Unknown (limited published intervention data)
Key_Publication: CheekAge publication pending full peer review (2024 preprint)
Notes: Non-invasive buccal sampling; consumer-friendly; gamified interface; potential conflict of interest with Sinclair supplement ventures

Measurement_Method: Blood sample analyzed by UPLC for IgG glycosylation patterns; pro-inflammatory agalactosylated glycans increase with age
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate (validated for immune aging and inflammatory status; less validated for mortality than epigenetic clocks)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Moderate (responds to lifestyle changes, diet, exercise, stress reduction, weight loss; changes detectable in 3-6 months)
Key_Publication: Kristic J et al. Glycans are a novel biomarker of chronological and biological ages. J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci. 2014;69(7):779-789
Notes: Unique glycomic perspective; captures immune/inflammatory aging; validated on >100000 samples; measures single dimension of aging

Developer: Elysium Health (co-founded by Leonard Guarente, MIT)
Measurement_Method: Saliva sample (mail-in kit); DNA methylation analysis via Illumina array; reports biological age and rate of aging across 10 aging areas
Correlation_With_Mortality: Unknown (based on validated clock algorithms but proprietary composite less independently validated)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Unknown (limited independent intervention studies)
Key_Publication: Elysium technical validation papers (proprietary)
Notes: Integration with Elysium supplement products (Basis NR + pterostilbene); saliva-based may differ from blood methylation; potential conflict of interest

Measurement_Method: Blood sample (mail-in kit); Illumina EPIC array; calculates Horvath, Hannum, PhenoAge, GrimAge2, DunedinPACE, DNAmTL, OMICmAge, SYMPHONYAge, immune cell composition
Correlation_With_Mortality: Strong (aggregates multiple validated clocks including GrimAge and DunedinPACE)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: High (includes DunedinPACE which has excellent intervention sensitivity; longitudinal tracking capability)
Commercial_Availability: Yes (TruDiagnostic, trudiagnostic.com; direct-to-consumer and clinician channels)
Key_Publication: Demidenko O et al. Rejuvant alpha-ketoglutarate and vitamins biological age study. Aging (Albany NY). 2021
Notes: Most comprehensive commercial epigenetic panel; exclusive DunedinPACE commercial license; largest consumer epigenetic dataset

Measurement_Method: Step counter and wearable device data (accelerometer); deep learning model predicts biological resilience and pace of aging from physical activity patterns
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate (DOSI resilience metric correlates with mortality in validation cohorts)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Unknown (wearable-derived metrics are inherently responsive to physical activity changes)
Key_Publication: Pyrkov TV et al. Longitudinal analysis of blood markers reveals progressive loss of resilience and predicts human lifespan limit. Nat Commun. 2021;12:2765
Notes: Novel wearable-based approach; non-invasive continuous monitoring; measures dynamic resilience rather than static age; requires consistent device wearing

Measurement_Method: Deep learning multimodal models trained on blood biochemistry, transcriptomics, microbiome, photographs, and other data types; multiple specialized clocks
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate to Strong (validated across multiple cohorts; blood-based clocks show mortality prediction)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Moderate (blood biochemistry clocks respond to metabolic and lifestyle interventions)
Commercial_Availability: Yes (Deep Longevity, deeplongevity.com; available via Young.AI app)
Key_Publication: Zhavoronkov A et al. Deep biomarkers of human aging. Aging (Albany NY). 2016;8(5):1021-1030; Mamoshina P et al. Nat Commun. 2018
Notes: Multiple specialized clocks (BloodAge, PhotoAge, MindAge, etc.); AI-driven approach; scalable; less mechanistic interpretability than epigenetic clocks

Measurement_Method: Standard blood test parameters (19-40 routine biomarkers: CBC, metabolic panel, lipids); neural network model predicts biological age
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate (validated for age prediction; indirect mortality association via individual biomarker correlations)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Moderate (routine blood parameters respond to metabolic, lifestyle, and pharmacological interventions)
Commercial_Availability: Yes (Deep Longevity; freely accessible online at aging.ai)
Cost_Approx: Free (web tool) to $50-$100 (with blood panel cost)
Key_Publication: Mamoshina P et al. Population-specific biomarkers of human aging. J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci. 2018;73(11):1482-1490
Notes: Accessible and low-cost; uses routine blood work; freely available online tool; less precise than epigenetic or proteomic clocks; affected by acute illness and fasting state

Developer: Ake Lu and Steve Horvath / UCLA
Measurement_Method: 140 CpG sites from Illumina 450K/EPIC array to estimate leukocyte telomere length from methylation patterns
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate (shorter DNAmTL predicts mortality, CHD, and some cancers independently of other clocks)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Low (limited data; may respond to telomerase-activating interventions)
Key_Publication: Lu AT et al. DNA methylation-based estimator of telomere length. Aging (Albany NY). 2019;11(16):5895-5923
Notes: Complementary telomere perspective; provides independent predictive information; less characterized for intervention sensitivity

Developer: Benoit Lehallier and Tony Wyss-Coray / Stanford
Measurement_Method: ~3000-5000 plasma proteins via SomaScan aptamer-based proteomics platform; ML model predicts biological age
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate to Strong (proteomic age acceleration associates with adverse health outcomes; non-linear aging waves at ages ~34, 60, 78)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Moderate (proteins are rapidly turned over and responsive; not as thoroughly validated as DunedinPACE for interventions)
Commercial_Availability: Research only (SomaLogic research services; some longevity clinics)
Key_Publication: Lehallier B et al. Undulating changes in human plasma proteome profiles across the lifespan. Nat Med. 2019;25(12):1843-1850
Notes: Captures organ-specific aging signals; directly measures functional proteins; mechanistically informative; expensive and requires specialized platform

Developer: Hamilton Oh and Tony Wyss-Coray / Stanford
Measurement_Method: Organ-enriched proteins from SomaScan platform; organ-specific aging scores for 11 major organs (brain, heart, liver, kidney, lung, intestine, muscle, pancreas, immune, fat, vasculature)
Correlation_With_Mortality: Strong (multi-organ accelerated aging ~ 50% increased mortality; organ-specific acceleration predicts organ-specific disease)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Unknown (early-stage; theoretical sensitivity based on protein turnover rates)
Key_Publication: Oh HS et al. Organ aging signatures in the plasma proteome track health and disease. Nature. 2023;624:164-172
Notes: Paradigm shift from whole-body to organ-specific aging; ~1 in 5 healthy adults 50+ have accelerated aging in at least one organ; enables targeted interventions

Developer: Nazish Sayed and David Furman / Stanford and Buck Institute; commercialized by Edifice Health
Measurement_Method: ~50 inflammatory cytokines and chemokines in blood via Luminex multiplex; deep learning model; key driver is CXCL9
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate to Strong (iAge acceleration predicts CVD, immune decline, multi-morbidity, and frailty)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: Moderate (responds to anti-inflammatory interventions; less characterized than epigenetic clocks)
Key_Publication: Sayed N et al. An inflammatory aging clock (iAge) based on deep learning. Nat Aging. 2021;1:598-615
Notes: Captures inflammaging dimension; CXCL9 identified as key driver; validated in Stanford 1000 Immunomes cohort; limited commercial availability

Measurement_Method: Standard immunoassay (ELISA) or multiplex platforms (Olink, SomaScan) from blood sample
Correlation_With_Mortality: Very Strong (one of the single most powerful protein mortality predictors; each doubling ~ 1.5-2x mortality risk)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: High (responds to exercise, weight loss, metformin, GLP-1 agonists)
Key_Publication: Wiklund FE et al. MIC-1/GDF15: a new marker of all-cause mortality. Aging Cell. 2010;9(6):1057-1064
Notes: Component of GrimAge; sentinel biomarker of multi-system aging; rises ~2-5 fold between ages 30-80; simple and inexpensive clinical test

Measurement_Method: Fried Phenotype: 5 criteria (weight loss, exhaustion, low activity, slow gait, weak grip); Rockwood: 30-70 health variable deficit accumulation; clinical assessment
Correlation_With_Mortality: Very Strong (one of the strongest clinical predictors of mortality in older adults, independent of age and comorbidities)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: High (responds to exercise, D+Q senolytics, GlyNAC, nutritional interventions)
Commercial_Availability: Yes (free clinical assessment; no lab test required)
Key_Publication: Fried LP et al. Frailty in older adults: evidence for a phenotype. J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci. 2001;56(3):M146-M156
Notes: FDA-accepted as composite functional endpoint; used in senolytic trials; no lab cost; subjective components; floor/ceiling effects in some populations

Measurement_Method: Handheld dynamometer (e.g., Jamar); maximum force in kg
Correlation_With_Mortality: Very Strong (each 5 kg decline ~ 15-20% increased mortality risk; predicts CVD mortality and disability)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: High (responds to exercise, nutritional interventions, GlyNAC, urolithin A)
Key_Publication: Leong DP et al. Prognostic value of grip strength. Lancet. 2015;386(9990):266-273
Notes: Simplest and cheapest aging biomarker; strong mortality predictor; standardized protocol; reflects sarcopenia and overall physical function

Developer: Multiple groups; Studenski et al. key validation
Measurement_Method: Timed walk over 4-6 meters; measured in meters per second (m/s)
Correlation_With_Mortality: Very Strong (<0.8 m/s significantly increased mortality; each 0.1 m/s increase ~ 12% reduced mortality risk)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: High (responds to exercise, D+Q, GlyNAC, physical therapy)
Commercial_Availability: Yes (free; requires only stopwatch and hallway)
Key_Publication: Studenski S et al. Gait speed and survival in older adults. JAMA. 2011;305(1):50-58
Notes: Called the sixth vital sign in geriatrics; FDA-accepted functional endpoint; free and universally accessible; reflects multi-system integration

Measurement_Method: Standard blood panel (~40+ biomarkers: glucose, hsCRP, LDL, HDL, triglycerides, HbA1c, albumin, CBC, hormones, vitamins); ML algorithm calculates InnerAge
Correlation_With_Mortality: Moderate (individual biomarkers are validated mortality predictors; composite InnerAge algorithm is proprietary and less externally validated)
Sensitivity_To_Interventions: High (standard blood biomarkers are highly responsive to diet, exercise, supplementation, and pharmacological interventions)
Key_Publication: Proprietary algorithm; published internal validation studies
Notes: Actionable recommendations; uses standard blood work; integrates wearable data; frequent retesting feasible; proprietary algorithm with limited peer-reviewed validation
